items.title: Wrong pyproject.toml is generated for local packages
items.body:
```python
from requirementslib import Requirement

Requirement.from_pipfile('mypackage', {"path": "./mypackage", "editable": True})
```
This creates a `pyproject.toml` under project root:
```toml
[build-system]
requires = []
build-backend = "setuptools.build_meta:__legacy__"
```
The `setuptools` is missing from `requires`, which causes failure in subsequent installations.

items.title: Pipfile package finder hangs on local dependency
items.body: see: https://github.com/timothycrosley/isort/blob/cd9c2f6e70196bd429d0179635e0fac2d034ac5e/isort/finders.py

items.title: Can't locate the correct file of special directives in setup.cfg
items.body:
## Example setup.cfg:
```ini
[metadata]
name = bug-test
version = attr: bug.__version__

[options]
packages = bug
python_requires = >=3.6
zip_safe = True

[bdist_wheel]
universal = 1
```
And folder tree:
```
bug
    __init__.py    <-- __version__ = 0.1.0
setup.cfg
```
## Steps to reproduce:

```python
from pathlib import Path
from requirementslib.models.setup_info import parse_setup_cfg

print(parse_setup_cfg(Path('setup.cfg').read_text(), Path('.').absolute().as_posix()))
```
## Result
```pytb
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File ".\parse_test.py", line 5, in <module>
    print(parse_setup_cfg(Path('setup.cfg').read_text(), Path('.').absolute().as_posix()))
  File "d:\workspace\pipenv\pipenv\vendor\requirementslib\models\setup_info.py", line 322, in parse_setup_cfg
    name, version = get_name_and_version_from_setupcfg(parser, package_dir)
  File "d:\workspace\pipenv\pipenv\vendor\requirementslib\models\setup_info.py", line 277, in get_name_and_version_from_setupcfg
    version = parse_special_directives(parser.get("metadata", "version"), package_dir)
  File "d:\workspace\pipenv\pipenv\vendor\requirementslib\models\setup_info.py", line 191, in parse_special_directives
    rv = ast_parse_attribute_from_file(path, attribute)
  File "d:\workspace\pipenv\pipenv\vendor\requirementslib\models\setup_info.py", line 1172, in ast_parse_attribute_from_file
    analyzer = ast_parse_file(path)
  File "d:\workspace\pipenv\pipenv\vendor\requirementslib\models\setup_info.py", line 1193, in ast_parse_file
    tree = ast.parse(read_source(path))
  File "d:\workspace\pipenv\pipenv\vendor\requirementslib\models\utils.py", line 1024, in read_source
    with open(path, "r", encoding=encoding) as fp:
FileNotFoundError: [Errno 2] No such file or directory: 'D:/Workspace/pipenv-bug-test\\bug\\bug'
```

items.title: annotation assignments are missing from the AST
items.body:
example:

```python
from typing import List

INSTALL_REQUIRES: List[str] = ["flask"]

setup(
    ...
    install_requires=INSTALL_REQUIRES
)
```

items.title: setup.py files with package names which return functions that can't be resolved must be executed
items.body:
per pypa/pipenv#4292 -- a `setup.py` with a package name that points at a function, e.g. `find_name()`, that then opens and reads a file (i.e. the value can't be determined by the AST parser), must be executed instead of returning None.

If we return `None`, the package will never land in the `Pipfile.lock`.

items.title: Requirement parse error when the name field is a function call
items.body:
Example setup.py:
```python
def get_name():
    return 'foo'

setup(
    name=get_name(),
    ...
)
```
`Requirement.from_line('-e .')` produces: `TypeError: expected string or bytes-like object`

Original issue: https://github.com/pypa/pipenv/issues/4292

items.title: AST Parser Matching Name assignments should choose last match
items.body:
Currently, the `setup.py` AST parser will look for matches by name when matching assignments in `setup.py`. If a name has been assigned multiple times, however, the first assignment is chosen instead of the most recent assignment, which can cause major problems for the parser which will be working with an incomplete / unparsed object.

For example, when unparsing the following `ast.BinOp` instance:

```python
	matches = entry['key'][0]['matches']
	matches = [x for x in matches if 'some_string' not in x]
	entry['key'][0]['matches'] = matches + other_list
```

the first assignment of `matches` is chosen, causing the following exception:

```console
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/home/techalchemy/git/requirementslib/src/requirementslib/models/setup_info.py", line 1201, in ast_parse_setup_py
    ast_analyzer.unmap_binops()
  File "/home/techalchemy/git/requirementslib/src/requirementslib/models/setup_info.py", line 729, in unmap_binops
    self.binOps_map[binop] = ast_unparse(binop, analyzer=self)
  File "/home/techalchemy/git/requirementslib/src/requirementslib/models/setup_info.py", line 1017, in ast_unparse
    left_item = unparse(item.left)
  File "/home/techalchemy/git/requirementslib/src/requirementslib/models/setup_info.py", line 1040, in ast_unparse
    items = unparse(analyzer.assignments[assignment])
  File "/home/techalchemy/git/requirementslib/src/requirementslib/models/setup_info.py", line 1140, in ast_unparse
    val = unparse(item.value, recurse=False)
  File "/home/techalchemy/git/requirementslib/src/requirementslib/models/setup_info.py", line 1000, in ast_unparse
    unparsed = unparse(item.value)
  File "/home/techalchemy/git/requirementslib/src/requirementslib/models/setup_info.py", line 1000, in ast_unparse
    unparsed = unparse(item.value)
  File "/home/techalchemy/git/requirementslib/src/requirementslib/models/setup_info.py", line 1004, in ast_unparse
    unparsed = unparsed[unparse(item.slice.value)]
TypeError: string indices must be integers

string indices must be integers
```

items.title: URI.get_username() and URI.get_password() replace literal plus signs with spaces
items.body:
## Description

[RFC 3986](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3986#section-3.2.1) specifies that the userinfo subcomponent of a URI may contain the sub-delim tokens, so it is okay to include a literal plus sign (not percent-encoded) there, I believe (if not, please feel free to close this issue!).

`model.url.URI` seems to assume that these fields are always percent-encoded, leading to the replacement of `+` with a space in `URI.get_username()` and `URI.get_password()` (which are called internally by `URI.to_string()`.

This is the root cause of pypa/pipenv#4271, which relies on this method for handling Git VCS URLs.

## Expected behaviour

Parsing and formatting a URI containing a userinfo component where either the username or password contain a literal plus character (`+`) should not alter the content of these fields.

## Suggested fix

If my understanding of the RFC as mentioned above is correct, `URI._parse_auth` should call `quote_plus` with the `safe` arg set to the [`sub-delim` tokens](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3986#section-2.2) from RFC 3986, preventing them from being escaped in the auth fields.

## Steps to reproduce

```python
from requirementslib.models.url import URI

u1 = URI.parse('git+https://foo+bar:foobar@example.org')
u2 = URI.parse('git+https://foo:bar+foobar@example.org')
print(f'{u1}, username={u1.username}, get_username()={u1.get_username()}, password={u1.password}, get_password()={u1.get_password()}, url={str(u1)}')
print(f'{u2}, username={u2.username}, get_username()={u2.get_username()}, password={u2.password}, get_password()={u2.get_password()}, url={str(u2)}')
```

yields

```
git+https://foo bar:----@example.org, username=foo+bar, get_username()=foo+bar, password=foobar, get_password()=foobar, url=git+https://foo bar:----@example.org
git+https://foo:----@example.org, username=foo, get_username()=foo, password=bar+foobar, get_password()=bar+foobar, url=git+https://foo:----@example.org
```

Note that the username and password fields are parsed correctly from the input but accessing them via `get_username()`/`get_password()` or formatting the URI as a string leads to the inadvertent replacement.

items.title: packages with setup functions parsed from a dictionary fail to return meaningful metadata

labels.name: dependencies
labels.description: Pull requests that update a dependency file

items.body:
Packages which provide a dictionary to the `setup` function via dictionary unpacking provide a metadata dictionary that contains a  base key of `None`.

We should check for this and only return the values in that case.

items.title: Named requirements collide with local files
items.body:
Named requirements with local files of the same name collide, causing installation errors. This is a regression.

E.g.:

```pycon
>>> import pathlib
>>> pathlib.Path("alembic").touch()
>>> from requirementslib.models.requirements import Requirement
>>> r = Requirement.from_line("alembic")
```

raises an error when it should return a named requirement.

items.title: Subdirectories are dropped from requirements with egg fragments
items.body: Requirements containing `#egg=<name>` drop their subdirectory fragments during parsing due to the `URI` parser retaining only the egg fragment.

items.title: Old Python specifiers can't be parsed correctly
items.body:
Original issue: https://github.com/pypa/pipenv/issues/4226

`django-robots` has `data-requires-python` of `>1.1.1`, which causes failure when parsing the specifier.

items.title: Direct URL requirements do not report as such
items.body:
Requirements parsed from `PEP508` style direct URLs do not report that they were parsed from a direct url and will not return a direct URL as their original line, even though the `URI` parser retains this metadata:

```python
>>> r = Requirement.from_line("vistir@ git+https://github.com/sarugaku/vistir.git@master")                                                                                    
>>> r.is_direct_url                                                                                                                                                           
False

>>> r.line_instance.is_direct_url                                                                                                                                             
False

>>> from requirementslib.models.requirements import Line                                                                                                                      
>>> l = Line("vistir@ git+https://github.com/sarugaku/vistir.git@master")                                                                                                     
>>> l.is_direct_url                                                                                                                                                           
False

>>> from requirementslib.models.url import URI                                                                                                                                
>>> parsed = URI.parse("vistir@ git+https://github.com/sarugaku/vistir.git@master")                                                                                           
>>> parsed.is_direct_url                                                                                                                                                      
True

>>> parsed.to_string()                                                                                                                                                        
'vistir@ git+https://github.com/sarugaku/vistir.git@master'
```

items.title: Wheel cache cannot be created without new global tempdir manager
items.body: new versions of pip use a `global_tempdir_manager` instance to manage creation of the wheel cache; we need to manage this context when creating our own wheel cache in `dependencies.py`

items.title: Markers reduced to only "deprecated" versions if any deprecated version exists
items.body:
Running `pipenv lock` on:

```
[[source]]
url = "https://pypi.python.org/simple"
verify_ssl = true
name = "pypi"

[packages]
requests="==2.19.1"
```

yields a lock file with:

```
{
...
        "urllib3": {
            "hashes": [
                "sha256:a68ac5e15e76e7e5dd2b8f94007233e01effe3e50e8daddf69acfd81cb686baf",
                "sha256:b5725a0bd4ba422ab0e66e89e030c806576753ea3ee08554382c14e685d117b5"
            ],
            "markers": "python_version >= '2.6' and python_version not in '3.0, 3.1, 3.2, 3.3' and python_version < '4'",
            "version": "==1.23"
        }
    },
...
}

```

even though `urllib3` also doesn't support 3.4.  The problem is due to how deprecated versions are handled [here](https://github.com/sarugaku/requirementslib/blob/bc30c3567198de98b69cb8b22337e3253a741d74/src/requirementslib/models/markers.py#L559)

I believe the correct behavior would be to add the deprecated list and current values together.  PR forthcoming...

items.title: AST Parsing should try to fail silently if possible
items.body: ast parsing currently fails to resolve all function names if only one attribute is too complex to resolve -- this usually doesn't matter so we should just move on (e.g. `pyinstaller@3.6` on python 2.7)

items.title: In setup_info, comparator `contains` is called incorrectly
items.body: [operator.contains](https://github.com/sarugaku/requirementslib/blob/master/src/requirementslib/models/setup_info.py#L682) should be called with swapped operands.  See the [documentation](https://docs.python.org/3/library/operator.html#operator.contains).

items.title: python_requires not correctly mapped to markers when micro version included
items.body:
This problem has to do with with when the setup file requires a version of python that includes a full version, e.g.:

```python
setup(
...
python_requires=">=3.6.1",
)
```

This gets mapped to the marker:

```python
"python_version >= '3.6.1'", 
```

in e.g. a Pipfile.lock, but **this fails** to work because `python_version` only include the major and minor version.  (See e.g. [PEP 508](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0508/)). 

A fix in this case may be to map to:

```python
"python_full_version >= '3.6.1'", 
```

*** EDIT ***:

An example module where this occurs is `prompt-toolkit` used by new versions of `ipython`.

items.title: URLs print masked usernames even when no username is provided
items.body: `URI` instances print `----` masked usernames even when no username is provided

items.title: parsing setup.cfg via setuptools is currently broken
items.body: the implementation of metadata parsing using `setuptools.read_configuration` in `models.setup_info.setuptools_parse_setup_cfg` is currently broken -- a dictionary of metadata is updated with a single element enclosed in `{}` (a set) which fails, and then a dictionary of `extras` is redefined using a list in a for loop, causing another failure.

items.title: We shouldn't install upgraded versions of test dependencies in CI
items.body: This can cause breaking behavior due to not respecting test dependency pins (e.g. `hypothesis` installs a version with a breaking API change)

items.title: AST parser for setup.py files doesn't map comparisons or BoolOps
items.body:
The AST parser fails to perform comparisons or boolean operations due to a lack of any mapping from the ast to equivalent functions, which can lead to half-parsed lists for `install_requires` as in, for instance, `azure-storage==0.36.0`, which contains the following:

```python
    install_requires=[
        'azure-common>=1.1.5',
        'cryptography',
        'python-dateutil',
        'requests',
    ] + (['futures'] if sys.version_info < (3,0) else []),
```

The conditional expression fails to parse, yielding an unusable result

items.title: Not all binary operators are mapped for translation when parsing setup.py
items.body: The AST parser responsible for managing the translation of `setup.py` nodes does not contain mappings for all possible operators in the `ast.binOp` type, which will cause issues when parsing any binary operators which are not currently mapped

items.title: AST parsing fails on non-utf8 setup.py files
items.body:
The AST parser simply dies on non-utf8 `setup.py` files.  One package I've encountered with this issue is `azure-storage`:

```pycon
>>> ast_parse_setup_py("/tmp/pkgs/azure-storage-0.36.0/setup.py")                                                                                                             
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/home/techalchemy/.virtualenvs/tempenv-74f7279776e1c/lib/python3.8/site-packages/requirementslib/models/setup_info.py", line 827, in ast_parse_setup_py
    ast_analyzer = ast_parse_file(path)
  File "/home/techalchemy/.virtualenvs/tempenv-74f7279776e1c/lib/python3.8/site-packages/requirementslib/models/setup_info.py", line 819, in ast_parse_file
    tree = ast.parse(read_source(path))
  File "/home/techalchemy/.pyenv/versions/3.8.1/lib/python3.8/ast.py", line 47, in parse
    return compile(source, filename, mode, flags,
  File "<unknown>", line 1
    ﻿#!/usr/bin/env python
    ^
SyntaxError: invalid character in identifier

invalid character in identifier (<unknown>, line 1)
```

I checked the encoding of the given file, revealing:

```pycon
>>> import chardet                                                                                                                                                            
>>> with open("/tmp/pkgs/azure-storage-0.36.0/setup.py", "rb") as fh: 
  2     encoding = chardet.detect(fh.read())                                                                                                                                  
>>> encoding                                                                                                                                                                  
{'encoding': 'UTF-8-SIG', 'confidence': 1.0, 'language': ''}
```

So it seems it's not a safe assumption that these are utf-8 encoded files and we should build in a fallback

This is a blocker on pypa/pipenv#3369

items.title: AST parsing of setup.py fails on non-addition type binOps
items.body:
For specific cases in complex `setup.py` parsing, `ast_unparse_setup_py` fails due to its lack of adequate mapping of `ast.binOps` operators.

One good example is when parsing the `setup.py` that accompanies `PyYAML`:

```pycon
>>> ast_parse_setup_py("/tmp/pkgs/PyYAML-5.3/setup.py")
...
  File "/home/techalchemy/.virtualenvs/tempenv-74f7279776e1c/lib/python3.8/site-packages/requirementslib/models/setup_info.py", line 664, in visit_BinOp
    left = ast_unparse(node.left, initial_mapping=True)
  File "/home/techalchemy/.virtualenvs/tempenv-74f7279776e1c/lib/python3.8/site-packages/requirementslib/models/setup_info.py", line 693, in ast_unparse
    unparsed = [unparse(el) for el in item.elts]
  File "/home/techalchemy/.virtualenvs/tempenv-74f7279776e1c/lib/python3.8/site-packages/requirementslib/models/setup_info.py", line 693, in <listcomp>
    unparsed = [unparse(el) for el in item.elts]
  File "/home/techalchemy/.virtualenvs/tempenv-74f7279776e1c/lib/python3.8/site-packages/requirementslib/models/setup_info.py", line 695, in ast_unparse
    unparsed = tuple([unparse(el) for el in item.elts])
  File "/home/techalchemy/.virtualenvs/tempenv-74f7279776e1c/lib/python3.8/site-packages/requirementslib/models/setup_info.py", line 695, in <listcomp>
    unparsed = tuple([unparse(el) for el in item.elts])
  File "/home/techalchemy/.virtualenvs/tempenv-74f7279776e1c/lib/python3.8/site-packages/requirementslib/models/setup_info.py", line 794, in ast_unparse
    return unparsed
UnboundLocalError: local variable 'unparsed' referenced before assignment

local variable 'unparsed' referenced before assignment
```

This is currently a release blocker for pypa/pipenv#3369

items.title: Python 2 ConfigParser instances can't read strings
items.body: Using python 2, `ConfigParser` objects don't come with a `read_string` method built in. They can, however, `readfp` from a `BytesIO` instance. Currently we are using `read_text()` to get the contents of `setup.cfg` files and passing the contents to `parse_setup_cfg`, but we can just tweak this to read & pass bytes and subsequently generate a buffer on python 2 to dodge attempts at reopening the file (which was the whole issue in the first place -- the file is sometimes deleted before we make it that far down in the call stack)

items.title: Build locations are deleted for local source directories before they can be referenced
items.body: When building a local source package via `SetupInfo` on master, the build directory created is temporary and is deleted by pip before it can be referenced and inspected for dependencies

items.title: Use github actions for automated releases
items.body: Adapt sarugaku/pip-shims#41 to automate releasing with github actions

items.title: Lockfile model access is broken for lockfiles which automatically determine their own location
items.body: When creating a new lockfile instance without calling the `load()` classmethod or passing any arguments (i.e. simply `chdir` to a directory with a lockfile and call `my_lockfile = Lockfile()`), requirementslib currently throws an `AttributeError` because the `lockfile.projectfile` instance has no attribute `lockfile`.

items.title: pipfile.__getitem__ throws a keyerror when accessing missing sections
items.body: This behavior is arguably not a bug but I would call it unexpected, and I would say the more correct behavior is probably to just generate the missing sections at load since one might expect to put a package into an empty section whether it was previously present or not.

items.title: Pipfile parsing is currently broken for pipfiles without sources
items.body: Parsing is also broken if pipfiles are loaded with a `sources` section rather than a `source` array of tables

items.title: Add support for hiding tokens (i.e. authentication without a separate password) in urls
items.body: Self explanatory

items.title: Update command to use new references from pip-shims
items.body: pip shims now provides shimmed functionality to avoid having to guard usage of things like `Resolver` and `PackageFinder` calls for each version of pip.

items.title: link objects no longer have is_artifact attributes
Pipfile.get_deps and Pipfile.get throw Attribute Error
items.body:
```
>>> file = Pipfile.load('.')
>>> file.get_deps()
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<input>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/home/matt/.local/share/virtualenvs/pipenv-setup-b3M9ZER-/lib/python3.7/site-packages/requirementslib/models/pipfile.py", line 193, in get_deps
    merge_items([deps, self.pipfile._data["packages"]])
AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute '_data'
```

```
>>> file.get('black')
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<input>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/home/matt/.local/share/virtualenvs/pipenv-setup-b3M9ZER-/lib/python3.7/site-packages/requirementslib/models/pipfile.py", line 198, in get
    return self.__getitem__(k)
  File "/home/matt/.local/share/virtualenvs/pipenv-setup-b3M9ZER-/lib/python3.7/site-packages/requirementslib/models/pipfile.py", line 214, in __getitem__
    retval = pipfile[k]
TypeError: 'NoneType' object is not subscriptable
```

this happens because `pipfile` attribute is not initialized upon `load`

items.title: as_requirements throws TypeError when there is local package
items.body:
```
>>> lockfile.as_requirements()
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<input>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/virtual-env/lib/python3.7/site-packages/requirementslib/models/lockfile.py", line 301, in as_requirements
    section = self.dev_requirements if dev else self.requirements
  File "virtual-env/lib/python3.7/site-packages/requirementslib/models/lockfile.py", line 277, in dev_requirements
    self._dev_requirements = list(self.get_requirements(dev=True, only=True))
  File "/virtual-env/lib/python3.7/site-packages/requirementslib/models/lockfile.py", line 272, in get_requirements
    yield Requirement.from_pipfile(k, v)
  File "/virtual-env/lib/python3.7/site-packages/requirementslib/models/requirements.py", line 2841, in from_pipfile
    r = FileRequirement.from_pipfile(name, pipfile)
  File "/virtual-env/lib/python3.7/site-packages/requirementslib/models/requirements.py", line 1894, in from_pipfile
    uri = pip_shims.shims.path_to_url(path)
TypeError: 'NoneType' object is not callable
```

There is a local package 
```
        "package_name": {
            "editable": true,
            "path": "."
        },
```
in my Pipfile.lock

Once I removed this key value pair. `as_requirements` runs successfully

items.title: iter_metadata would unexpectly find another package's metadata
items.body:
https://github.com/sarugaku/requirementslib/blob/d252fd07fa12df231ba8858ecf16215b936307c1/src/requirementslib/models/setup_info.py#L455-L473

`iter_metadata()` scans metadata that ends with given pattern inside a path **recursively**, which would return unexpected results in some cases, here is the directory tree of one:
```
├───.venv    # We have a .venv folder here
│   ├───Include
│   ├───Lib
│   │   └───site-packages
│   │       ├───pip
│   │       ├───pip-19.0.3.dist-info   # pip metadata will be returned
├───src
│   ├───requirementslib
...
```

Testing:
```python
r = requirements.Requirement.from_line('-e .')
print(r.ireq)
```
The possible solution is to change the DFS method to BFS.

items.title: ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'pkg_resources.extern'
items.body:
I was trying to install https://github.com/pypa/pipenv `master` branch, which depends on https://github.com/sarugaku/requirementslib (though it has its copy in `vendor/` directory for some reason), and when run it fails with:

```
% pipenv
Traceback (most recent call last):
[...SNIPPED...]
  File "/usr/lib/python3.7/site-packages/pipenv/project.py", line 30, in <module>
    from .vendor.requirementslib.models.utils import get_default_pyproject_backend
  File "/usr/lib/python3.7/site-packages/pipenv/vendor/requirementslib/__init__.py", line 9, in <module>
    from .models.lockfile import Lockfile
  File "/usr/lib/python3.7/site-packages/pipenv/vendor/requirementslib/models/lockfile.py", line 15, in <module>
    from .requirements import Requirement
  File "/usr/lib/python3.7/site-packages/pipenv/vendor/requirementslib/models/requirements.py", line 49, in <module>
    from .setup_info import (
  File "/usr/lib/python3.7/site-packages/pipenv/vendor/requirementslib/models/setup_info.py", line 19, in <module>
    import pkg_resources.extern.packaging.requirements as pkg_resources_requirements
ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'pkg_resources.extern'
```

I don't understand the concept but apparently `pkg_resources.extern` is broken:
- https://github.com/pypa/setuptools/issues/1383
- https://github.com/pypa/pip/issues/5429
- https://bugs.archlinux.org/task/58670

And so in ArchLinux package of https://github.com/pypa/setuptools they simply removed the _extern_ functionality: https://git.archlinux.org/svntogit/packages.git/tree/trunk/PKGBUILD?h=packages/python-setuptools&id=001edbba7669215db7c853ca4fc8b35f09f044f8#n26
```
  rm -r setuptools-$pkgver/{pkg_resources,setuptools}/{extern,_vendor}

  # Upstream devendoring logic is badly broken, see:
  # https://bugs.archlinux.org/task/58670
  # https://github.com/pypa/pip/issues/5429
  # https://github.com/pypa/setuptools/issues/1383
  # The simplest fix is to simply rewrite import paths to use the canonical
  # location in the first place
```

Can this library be changed to not depend on `pkg_resources.extend`? Apparently it's broken for some time and according to the comment above, its use can be replaced with canonical import paths.

items.title: Pipfile failed to load when trying to lower() tomlkit's Bool object
`(Pipfile|Lockfile).load` does not fail if the schema does not match plette model.
items.body:
In the docs there is the following example:
```python
from requirementslib import Pipfile
pf = Pipfile.load('/home/hawk/git/pypa-pipenv')
```
consider a `Pipfile` that has the `name` missing from `[[source]]` which in `plette` is required https://github.com/sarugaku/plette/blob/master/src/plette/models/sources.py#L14 

The `pf` now is basically unusable because it is allowed to fail silently see https://github.com/sarugaku/requirementslib/blob/master/src/requirementslib/models/pipfile.py#L265 w/o being able to control that behavior. 

I have two questions about this:
- why allow loading when the schema does not match?
- it this the same validation that is applied by `pipenv`?

items.title: Setup.py AST parsing fails when encountering additive lists
items.body: The current implementation of the AST parser stumbles on `ast.BinOp` parsing

items.title: Requirement lines with encapsulating quotes are not handled correctly
items.body: Quotes should be stripped, but only if they encapsulate the line (i.e. don't strip a trailing quote if it doesn't have a matching quote at the beginning of the line)

items.title: Enhance requirements,txt compatible line generation when writing markers
items.body: Currently when writing markers, our format is not compatible with the proper `requirements.txt` format or with the standard `pip install` format (depending on whether we handle this with `as_list` or not. This needs to be resolved for writing out requirements in pipenv as part of a refactor of `pip_install`, and I am exanding some test functionality here as well so I figured i'd track this in a separate issue from #77

items.title: Error in test_local_req
items.body:
I am running test offline.

```
[   65s] [gw2] linux2 -- Python 2.7.16 /usr/bin/python2
[   65s] 
[   65s] self = <CallInfo when='setup' exception: >
[   65s] func = <function <lambda> at 0x7f131dba9b18>, when = 'setup'

[   65s]

[   65s]         #: context of invocation: one of "setup", "call",

[   65s] >           self.result = func()

... and ater this it bubbles down through pytest and pluggy source files to fail in pytest:

```

What am I doing wrong, please? It seems nobody else has a problem with this test...

items.title: LRU caching doesn't work when passing a tuple of tuples
items.body:
When calling `requirementslib.models.markers.cleanup_pyspecs` with a `SpecifierSet` instance, the given instance is split into a set of tuples and then converted to a tuple for hashing (for `lru_cache` compatibility specifically).

This doesn't seem to work, and it causes a lot of issues. We just need to drop the `lru_cache` from the specified function

items.title: AST Parser occassionally hits recursion error parsing functions in python 2
parsing setup.cfg for attr: syntax fails when package dir is in setup.py
items.body: When `package_dir` metadata is stored in `setup.py` but dynamic access happens in `setup.cfg` (e.g. `version: attr: requirementslib.__version__`), the lookup fails because we can't find the correct package directory to place on the path.

items.title: AST parsing fails when setup.py is called with fully qualified functions
items.body: `setuptools.setup()` for example is not captured by the AST parser, but it should be

items.title: Handle `InvalidMetadataError` for existing but invalid wheel files
items.body: Sometimes we can build or acquire a wheel but it isn't valid, see pypa/pipenv#3692

items.title: parsing name from paths always returns 'wheel'
Merging markers always uses 'or' operator, but should 'and' on non-similar operators
items.body: Only markers with the same variable should be `or` combined, everything else should be `and` combined

items.title: setup.cfg support does not have parity with setuptools
items.body:
One example:

```ini
[metadata]
name = whatever
version = attr: mypackage.__version__
```

```
  File "requirementslib/models/requirements.py", line 418, in requirement
    self.parse_requirement()
  File "requirementslib/models/requirements.py", line 946, in parse_requirement
    if self.setup_info and self.setup_info.name:
  File "requirementslib/models/requirements.py", line 739, in setup_info
    self.setup_info = self.get_setup_info()
  File "requirementslib/models/requirements.py", line 752, in setup_info
    self.specifier = setup_info.version
  File "requirementslib/models/requirements.py", line 356, in specifier
    self.specifiers = SpecifierSet(spec)
  File "packaging/specifiers.py", line 581, in __init__
    parsed.add(LegacySpecifier(specifier))
  File "packaging/specifiers.py", line 84, in __init__
    raise InvalidSpecifier("Invalid specifier: '{0}'".format(spec))
packaging.specifiers.InvalidSpecifier: Invalid specifier: '==attr: fatek.__version__'
```

setup.cfg supports various [directives](https://setuptools.readthedocs.io/en/latest/setuptools.html#configuring-setup-using-setup-cfg-files). Either all of them need to be supported, or a fallback to setuptools needs to be implemented if directives are encountered.

items.title: Loading pipfile fails due to failed conversion between tomlkit array and tuple
items.body: Currently, `Pipfile.load()` fails due to failed loading of extras during conversion from `plette.PackageCollection` or `plette.Package` to `Requirement.extras` for example.  We really need a helper function to convert tomlkit types to python types

items.title: PEP508 style URLs should raise helpful error when parsing egg fragments in url
items.body: If users provide a pep-508 compliant URL except they also supply a `#egg=name` fragment, we currently simply fail resolution -- we could raise a proper error with helpful information here or we could simply strip the egg fragment during resolution

items.title: attrs minimum dependency
items.body:
```console
[   32s] [149/230] cumulate python2-attrs-17.4.0-lp151.2.2
...
[   86s] ImportError while loading conftest '/home/abuild/rpmbuild/BUILD/requirementslib-1.4.2/tests/conftest.py'.
[   86s] /usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/six.py:709: in exec_
[   86s]     exec("""exec _code_ in _globs_, _locs_""")
[   86s] tests/conftest.py:10: in <module>
[   86s]     import requirementslib.utils
[   86s] ../../BUILDROOT/python-requirementslib-1.4.2-lp151.3.1.x86_64/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/requirementslib/__init__.py:9: in <module>
[   86s]     from .models.lockfile import Lockfile
[   86s] ../../BUILDROOT/python-requirementslib-1.4.2-lp151.3.1.x86_64/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/requirementslib/models/lockfile.py:15: in <module>
[   86s]     from .requirements import Requirement
[   86s] ../../BUILDROOT/python-requirementslib-1.4.2-lp151.3.1.x86_64/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/requirementslib/models/requirements.py:43: in <module>
[   86s]     from .setup_info import SetupInfo, _prepare_wheel_building_kwargs
[   86s] ../../BUILDROOT/python-requirementslib-1.4.2-lp151.3.1.x86_64/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/requirementslib/models/setup_info.py:454: in <module>
[   86s]     class Extra(object):
[   86s] ../../BUILDROOT/python-requirementslib-1.4.2-lp151.3.1.x86_64/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/requirementslib/models/setup_info.py:456: in Extra
[   86s]     requirements = attr.ib(factory=frozenset, cmp=True, type=frozenset)
[   86s] E   TypeError: attrib() got an unexpected keyword argument 'factory'
```

A quick scan through history of attrs suggests this is the functionality needed https://github.com/python-attrs/attrs/commit/780e1e5e1ea9d712e4df59f17fa1c8d4d3febcd5 , and thus the minimum version needed is at least 18.1.0

items.title: Performance is considerably degraded since 1.4.0
items.body:
- Performance has degraded considerably due to downloading VCS and file requirements
- Requirements are downloaded to parse names, dependencies, etc
- As of `1.4.1` this is done eagerly rather than lazily

items.title: Local editable file requirements are converted to ssh inadvertently
Repository handling doesn't respect the source directory argument
items.body: Currently, `src_dir` is simply ignored for non-local vcs requirements which are instead cloned to a random location and discarded after resolution

items.title: local paths and files are traversed depth first, but should be breadth first
items.body: For example, searching `pipenv` began by looking in forlders, but the target folder `pipenv.egg-info` is in the (provided) root...

items.title: Expose `is_pep517` and `build_backend` at top level of requirement object
items.body: This will allow us to more easily determine how to build a requirement

items.title: Supress stdout from pip vcs operations
items.body:
- Pip VCS operations somewhat randomly output stdout
- supress this output possibly by overriding `run_command` and giving it a default `show_stdout=False`

ref: pypa/pipenv#3305

items.title: fix patch function for plette
items.body: - Cut a quick pointrelease with a fix for the broken patch function for plette once we can verify that the new approach works

items.title: Extras are not currently parsed prperly when parsing setup.cfg
Local file requirements with extras are parsed incorrectly
items.body: Ref: pypa/pipenv#3230

items.title: Ref parsing is broken when ref names  contain slashes
Pipfile loader loads invalid data which fails cerberus validation
items.body: Data loaded by the pipfile loader fails cerberus validation, I think the `pipfile._data` attribute needs to be an explicitly cast `dict` of a list of dictionaries in the `source` attribute

items.title: Improve support for parsing names and dependencies from non-wheels
items.body:
- Unpack and build local and remote archives
- Parse and load dependencies from those archives
- Load requirements from sdists locally
- Parse and load `pyproject.toml`
- Parse and load `setup.cfg`
- Support for ast parsing `setup.py`? Is that faster / more accurate?
- What needs to happen for pep 508 style direct url support?

items.title: Support PEP 508 urls
Improve name detection from local and remote archives
Look into AST parsing for setup.py
Parse and load `setup.cfg`
Load dependency information from local paths
Unpack and build local and remote archives for parsing
Add pyproject.toml support
items.body: - Add support for parsing and loading `pyproject.toml` files

items.title: Add support and indicators for pep 508 style direct URL requirements
items.body:
- Add a way to check whether a file or url requirement is meant to be handled as a direct url requirement
- Allows us to work around the fact that both `pip` and `wheel` are currently broken

items.title: name 'ireq_from_line' is not defined
items.body:
```

    return ireq_from_line(
NameError: name 'ireq_from_line' is not defined
```

I think there are more. These are very easy to catch with flake8.

items.title: Import structures are incredibly slow and need to be reworked
items.body: Restructure imports to avoid unnecessary performance hits

items.title: VCS Requirements Drop Subdirectories
items.body: - Should be used for determining setup paths

items.title: hg repositories can't acquire commit hashes
items.body: - We shouldn't be invoking `get_revision_sha` directly (see https://github.com/pypa/pipenv/issues/3090#issuecomment-433628424 for more info)

items.title: don't leak requests sessions
items.body: Explicitly call `session.close()`

items.title: Enable merging of dev and non-dev dependencies
items.body:
If the same dependency appears in both the dev and default sections, we really need to take into account that the dependency very well may not conflict between dev and default when resolving the lockfile.

We need two mechanisms for handling this, because merging a set of dev dependencies into the default section may cause resolution conflicts and we will need a way to sort those out (this is going to be a behavioral change as people have been using the dev section to ensure that certain dependencies are explicitly superseded by others).

Here we are just providing the interface to allow merging in both pipfiles and lockfiles, where it will now be possible to lock each section separately.

ref: pypa/pipenv#2330

items.title: Pipfile and Pipfile.lock currently fail to load if they don't exist
items.body: - Provide interface for generation of both file types

items.title: Fix import and export of Pipfile and Pipfile.lock
items.body: - Importing from `Pipfile` and `Pipfile.lock` both are buggy, add in support for both reading and writing consistently

items.title: Allow inline markers to be optional
items.body: Markers on editable requirements are broken when rendered out inline (i.e. not to a file), allow them to be optional

items.title: Fix Requirement Conversions
items.body:
- Markers on editable requirements are broken when rendered out inline (i.e. not to a file), allow them to be optional
- Importing from `Pipfile` and `Pipfile.lock` both are buggy, add in support for both reading and writing consistently
- Provide interface for generation of both file types

items.title: Named Requirements are outputting canonicalized names by default in installrequirements
TypeError: 'module' object is not callable
items.body:
I believe that the latest release is causing our builds to start failing. 4 days ago this build worked:

https://circleci.com/gh/grow/grow/3317

But with no changes to the files it now fails:

https://circleci.com/gh/grow/grow/3340

With this error:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/local/bin/pipenv", line 11, in <module>

    rv = self.invoke(ctx)

```

items.title: Markers in requirements.txt is not working for editable package
items.body:
Current pipenv or requirementslib will output editable package in ```requirements.txt``` like this ```-e git+https://github.com/requests/requests.git@883caaf145fbe93bd0d208a6b864de9146087312#egg=requests ; python_version == '2.7'```

But acutally markes such as ```python_version``` is not working. In python 3, requests will still be installed by ```pip install -r requirements.txt```

I found that in https://github.com/pypa/pip/issues/4530, it looks like the correct format should be ```-e "git+https://github.com/requests/requests.git@883caaf145fbe93bd0d208a6b864de9146087312#egg=requests ; python_version == '2.7'"``` with ```"``` quoted :cry:

items.title: Editable package wtih ref using @ is not supported properly
items.body:
Package such as ```requests = {git = "https://github.com/requests/requests.git@883caaf", editable = true}``` will be parsed to followings in ```pipfile_entry```.

```
"requests": {
            "editable": true,
            "git": "https://github.com/requests/requests.git@883caaf",
            "ref": "883caaf145fbe93bd0d208a6b864de9146087312"
        }
```

But the correct format should be:
```
"requests": {
            "editable": true,
            "git": "https://github.com/requests/requests.git@883caaf145fbe93bd0d208a6b864de9146087312",
        }
```
or 
```
"requests": {
            "editable": true,
            "git": "https://github.com/requests/requests.git",
            "ref": "883caaf145fbe93bd0d208a6b864de9146087312"
        }
```

This makes ```pipenv install``` failed since ```-e git+https://github.com/requests/requests.git@883caaf@883caaf145fbe93bd0d208a6b864de9146087312#egg=pytest``` doesn't exist actually.

items.title: VCS requirement lines are no longers tored properly due to new requirement generation process
items.body: Should store original inputs to make sure we can convert back and forth while also moving to usable URIs

items.title: Editable packages with markers in requirements.txt can not be installed by pip
items.body:
Currently, editable package with markers generated by requirementslib will output forms like ```-e git+https://github.com/PyCQA/pylint.git@8682a220911a9c22286089e08f7e77b7b15d990b#egg=pylint; python_version >= '3.4'```

It can not be installed by ```pip install -r requirements.txt```, ```Invalid requirement: 'pylint;'``` error will be raised.

Adding whitespace before ```;``` will make it can be installed, such as ```-e git+https://github.com/PyCQA/pylint.git@8682a220911a9c22286089e08f7e77b7b15d990b#egg=pylint ; 
 python_version >= '3.4'```

Here are some [examples](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0496/#id7) provided in PEP496, which all have spaces before ```;```.

```
pywin32 >=1.0 ; sys_platform == 'win32'
unittest2 >=2.0,<3.0 ; python_version == '2.4' or python_version == '2.5'
backports.ssl_match_hostname >= 3.4 ; python_version < '2.7.9' or (python_version >= '3.0' and python_version < '3.4')
```

Here is the pip version I tested.

```
✗ pip --version
pip 18.0 from /home/user/.local/share/virtualenvs/myvirtualenv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pip (python 3.6)
```
